_header: Earth upon earth is waxen and wrought
Note: For the A-version see 6292; for the B-version see 1170, 6369; for still others see 1167, 6293.
Subjects: mortality; transitoriness, of world; transitoriness, of life; death, approach of
Bibliographic Ghosts: London, Wellcome Historical Medical Library 673 [olim Phillipps 18134; Quaritch Sale. Cat. 164] , f. 9: see 1170.

CULIi49.First Lines:
Erthe vpon erth is waxin and wroughtErthe takys on erthe a nobylay
                    of nought…
CULIi49.Last Lines:
…And toke erth from sorowe þue erth for to spedeThe ryght
                    wey to heuene blys Ihesu cryst vs lede
CULIi49.Editions:
Murray,  Hilda M. R.,
                        ed.  
             The Middle English Poem Erthe upon Erthe, printed from 24
                manuscripts.
EETS
         o.s. 141 (1911); repr. 1964: 32-4.

BLRoy17Axvi.First Lines:
Erth opon erth is vappyd & wroghtErth has takyn of erth
                    anobylte o noght…
BLRoy17Axvi.Last Lines:
…Erth wroth in erth& [as] moldwarp in moldAnd yit sal
                    erth& lang er þen he wold
BLRoy17Axvi.Editions:
Pope,  Nancy. 
             “Erthe upon Erthe Revisited.” 
             Journal of the Early Book Society
         21 (2018): 53-95: 78-80.
